One of the first public-key cryptosystems and is widely used for secure data transmission in the world.
An asymmetric key encryption algorithm for public-key cryptography which is based on the Diffie–Hellman key exchange.
An approach to public-key cryptography based on the algebraic structure of elliptic curves over finite fields.
A cryptographic one-way hash function containing a string of digits created, designed to protect the integrity of a piece of data.
A series of cryptographic hash functions published by NIST as a U.S. Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS).
A specific type of message authentication code (MAC) involving a cryptographic hash function and a secret cryptographic key.
A mathematical scheme for presenting the authenticity of digital messages or documents.
The practice of concealing a file, message, image, or video within another file, message, image, or video.
